How to choose a timestep (dt)?
:::

:::{.ddm-box style="font-family:EB Garamond It;border-color:transparent"}

The timestep must be much smaller than the fastest vibrations in your system.

- If timestep is too large → atoms “overshoot” → energy drift, instability, or bonds break.

- If timestep is too small → simulation is safe but unnecessarily slow.

Take the example of Halide Perovskite:

The fastest motions are bond stretching of Pb–Br / Pb–I / Cs–X and Br–Br / I–I interactions.

Typical bond vibrations are on the order of 10–100 THz (period ≈ 0.01–0.1 ps = 10–100 fs).

Rule of thumb: timestep ≲ 1/10 to 1/20 of the shortest vibrational period.

So:

If vibrational period ≈ 10 fs, then timestep ≲ 1 fs.

If vibrational period ≈ 20 fs, then timestep ≲ 2 fs.

How to choose a dumping factors?
:::

:::{.ddm-box style="font-family:EB Garamond It;border-color:transparent"}

For Nose-Hoover thermostat, typical choice for temp is 100 x dt and for pressure is 1000 x dt.


:::

:::{.ddm-head onclick="toggleBox(this)" style="border-bottom: px solid red;font-family:EB Garamond It"}

How to choose run value?
:::

:::{.ddm-box style="font-family:EB Garamond It;border-color:transparent"}

Use the formulas below:

$$simulated time required = \frac{\Delta T}{cooling rate}$$

$$number of steps = \frac{simulated time}{timestep}$$
